poem:
**Beezel's Whisper**

In a lone house, frosted cold,  
Where time's sinister tales unfold,  
Walls echo shrieks, shadows dance—  
Horror's grin, a sly askance.  
Amidst the frost, impish glints gleam,  
Laughter's slice in night's cruel dream,  
Fradkins weave, a spectral show,  
Darkness wrapped in winter's glow.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Beezel review – impish jump-scare machine follows single house’s horrific history Although there’s a fair amount of seasonally appropriate snow on display, this horror feature represents a stonking slice of counter-programming for the festive season, given there is nothing merry in the least about it. That said, there are sly flashes of tongue-in-cheek humour throughout from married co-writers Aaron Fradkin (also the film’s director) and Victoria Fratz Fradkin (one of the film’s leads). Consequently, Beezel". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
